title: Six Prince George’s middle schools selected to be built through public-private partnership
text:
The school system in Prince George’s County has selected six middle schools that will be rebuilt or newly constructed through a public-private partnership.

The schools that will be rebuilt are Drew-Freeman Middle School, Hyattsville Middle School, Kenmoor Middle School and Walker Mill Middle School.

In addition, two new middle schools are to be constructed in the Adelphi area and in the southern part of the county, likely in the Fort Washington area, said Christian Rhodes, chief of staff to schools chief Monica Goldson.

The school board approved a resolution outlining the new locations in its meeting Thursday night. Prince George’s school system is the first in the country to use the P3 model to build such a large cohort of its schools.

Leaders say they hope the arrangement will help reduce the county’s $8.5 billion construction backlog by cutting costs and increasing the speed with which schools are built.

Rhodes said exact locations for the new schools will be determined after the private company is selected through the request for proposals process, which he said will likely begin this winter.

The schools were chosen by system officials based on a 2017 study of conditions in every school in the system, which is the second-largest in the state. Rhodes said they decided to focus on building one type of school to increase efficiency in terms of construction costs and that they focused on geographical diversity.

He said there will be a focus on requiring that minority and local businesses be involved at every stage of the process, which includes designing the building, construction and maintenance.

The private company that the school system selects will design the building and finance its construction; county and state funding, including for payments to the contractor, will kick in once students are in the building. The schools will have to meet the same safety and code regulations as all school system buildings.

The contract will be for 33 years — approximately three years for building and 30 years of the company handling maintenance.
